projects.project_description: My master thesis revolved around creating a real-time deformation system for cars in video games. The biggest concern was creating visually plausible deformations within the time budget of a video game. A Unity3D project handles the run-time and uses a library to compute the deformations.

Cube Fusion is a cooperative puzzle game for two players. The main focus of this project was on the game and level design, which was motivated by the objective to teach teenagers the basic approach to progamming. The players have to discuss the solution to the level before programming their character's actions. The simulation can then be started and the players will see, whether their characters can solve the level together. The project consists of a server and a client, which communicate via a TCP/IP protocol.

An App I developed for TTE Europe GmbH that can scan barcodes of different types and sends them to their Rest API. Made use of modern design patterns such as MVVM, Dependency Injection and Loosely Coupled Components.

This is a modern implementation of Konami's 80s classic TimePilot, which was developed as a final project for the course Game Engine Architecture. The implementation uses design patterns such as the observer pattern, the component pattern or the object pool pattern, to decouple and optimize the code.

This is a proof of concept for a game that relies entirely on its physics simulation. Objects in the game are represented by spring-particle systems. These systems are physically evaluated in the game loop to compute forces, accelerations and velocites each frame.
